goals: ECY's goals for the coming year revolves around addressing the "twin pandemics" present today, COVID-19 and racism's ongoing presence in our society. We are expanding our Undoing Racism team and will be meeting more regularly, as well as re imagining what worship and community looks like with today's restriction. We are also reforming our Congregational Council, with the goal of getting as many undergraduate voices involved in the Episcopal Church at Yale.

name: The Moderate Party
mission: We, the Moderate Party, are a community devoted to political change. As such, we seek both to develop our Members as people and leaders, and to develop a new vision of practical, center-left politics. Our means are not only spirited discussion and formal debate of the politics and policies that divide our country but also collaboration with local leaders to produce something to show for our vision. We value pragmatic policy debate and discussions on salient political issues. We seek to bring our ideas to the outside world, and the outside world to best develop them. Together, we strive to advance the Party, the Yale Political Union, and this country.

name: The Women's Network
mission: The Women's Network at Yale is an intercollegiate organization focused on connecting and empowering women in the professional workplace, and creating a social community of ambitious, hard-working women.  We host career-focused events for women in all areas of study to be directly introduced to successful women in their fields and to hear from them in an open and candid discussion setting. We also host professional training bootcamps, career symposiums, networking events, Q&A panels, social events, and more. As an organization that hosts many large-scale events, we are able to differentiate ourselves by providing our members the opportunity to network across a much more extensive list and in many diverse areas. Our TWN Yale members become part of the greater TWN National organization, where we have over 30,000 members across the country and 142 chapters across college campuses. Ultimately, joining TWN will enable members to meet and connect with high-achieving individuals on both the Yale campus and around the nation, authentically network with powerful industry leaders, gain insight into traditional and unconventional careers, build confidence, gain leadership experience, and access exclusive internship and job opportunities.

name: The Yale Alley Cats - An Undergraduate A Cappella Singing Group
mission: The Yale Alley Cats is a world-renowned undergraduate a-cappella group founded in 1943. Our mission is to sing wonderful music together, become better musicians through vocal performance and rehearsal, to share our music to Yale's campus and audiences across the world, and, most of all, to cultivate meaningful friendships that last a lifetime. Although initially founded as a Jazz group, our over-400-song repertoire ranges all the way from Harry Styles to Michael Jackson. As the first internationally-touring undergraduate group at Yale, The Yale Alley Cats has funded trips to Hong Kong, Sydney, Istanbul, and Paris, London, and Geneva on our most recent tour. We've had the pleasure of performing for icons such as President Barack Obama, collaborated with a Grammy-winning songwriter, and released several albums, with a new album coming this year! As one of Yale's oldest a-cappella groups, The Yale Alley Cats strive to uphold the strong tradition of a-cappella music that has become such a signature of Yale's student life.

name: The Yale Undergraduate Literary Society
mission: Emulating the seminar format, the Yale Undergraduate Literary Society aims to provide a space for those interested in conversations on topics and issues related to difference, culture, humanity, philosophy, history, and politics considered in mainly literary contexts. We practice articulating complicated ideas on issues members care about and teasing out left-over ideas from classes, events, and news. Speaker events consist of inviting Yale faculty, visiting authors, museum curators, etc. to lead discussions. People from all majors and all backgrounds are encouraged to join!
goals: The Yale Undergraduate Literary Society aims to provide a community for students to reflect aloud on topics they care deeply about, like identity, culture, difference, grief, humanity, etc. It would also serve as a student workshop space for members to read and review one another's papers. The larger impacts of this club are its public events like: open discussions, interviews with authors, film screenings (plus discussion), and literature symposiums. Because of the broad nature of the discipline of comparative literature - the core attitude of this society -  we would easily be able to collaborate with other on-campus culture groups, music groups, art groups, film groups, and literary publications.

name: The Yale Women's Center - An Undergraduate Organization
mission:
The Women's Center works across issues and identities toward collective liberation. Gender and sexuality have historically been central to our work and now serve as one of many points of entry into intersectional struggles and coalition building.
We seek to foster a self-critical and self-reflective community, intentionally directing our time, resources, and programming toward dismantling systems of oppression through education and action. We aim to provide a physical and intellectual space where all are able to collaborate, learn, and unlearn without judgment. We strive to make our work accessible to everyone who wishes to engage with it, firmly believing that this work cannot and should not be done in isolation.
The Women's Center may be spatially enclosed within and funded by Yale, but all work within the university is intertwined with New Haven. We strive to build a deep and long-standing relationship with the city: realizing our mission demands that our community and our efforts extend far beyond our campus.

name: Trans@Yale: An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The three goals of Trans@Yale are: to provide a safe space for transgender and/or non-binary students to form a community that provides emotional support and any needed medical advice; to work with the Yale administration to provide respect and support, individually and institutionally, for trans and non-binary students; and to engage with larger-scale sociopolitical advocacy and activism around issues affecting the trans community as well as other communities fighting for rights and recognition. The first goal will be achieved through hosting social events and meetings where students can be themselves and feel comfortable and safe, as well as hosting workshops and talks on key trans issues. The second goal will be achieved through student activism, and also by working with the Office of LGBTQ Resources and the Yale Administration to find and rewrite policies that currently exclude trans/non-binary students and/or make being trans and participating in a Yale-affiliated activity unusually difficult. The third goal will be achieved also through student activism, as well as collaboration with other on-campus organizations and New Haven groups.

name: Tropical Resources Institute
mission: Founded in 1983, the Tropical Resources Institute (TRI) is an interdisciplinary, non-degree-granting program located within the Yale School of the Environment (YSE). TRI serves to facilitate and support student research and outreach activities throughout the tropics, primarily through granting research fellowships. TRI works closely with YSE students, advising them on research design, proposal development, and field methods, as well as facilitating in-country collaborations and partnerships with organizations and institutions working in the tropics. Within the broader Yale community, TRI serves as a clearinghouse for research and educational activities pertaining to tropical countries, societies, and environments.
benefits:
Research: Supporting interdisciplinary, problem-oriented student research on the most complex challenges confronting the conservation and management of tropical environments and natural resources worldwide.
Training: Training students to be leaders in this area by building linkages across the natural and social sciences and between theory and practice.
Networking: Providing a forum to support and connect the initiatives of the Yale community in developing applied research, partnerships, and programs in the tropics.

name: Undergraduate Production
mission:
Undergraduate Production (UP) was established in 2000 to ensure safe practices in the planning, production, and presentation of undergraduate performing arts events. Over the subsequent years, Yale College's performing arts culture has grown to encompass over 400 events, 2,500 students, and 30,000 audience experiences annually.
Yale University has a vast and vibrant performing arts culture. Within this rich environment, UP works exclusively with Yale undergraduates to ensure that their work gets the attention and support it needs. UP provides training and technical support for comedy, dance, music, opera, spoken word, theater, and interdisciplinary performance genres. We work on everything from large-scale projects, such as operas featuring dozens of cast members and musicians, to informal poetry slams.
Regardless of scope and scale, all student productions must be planned and developed in a manner that ensures the safety of the production team and the audience. UP exists to fulfill this mandate as we support both the artistic vision and the highest level of safety for each undergraduate production.

mission:
The University Church in Yale is a student-focused church welcoming Christian students of all backgrounds, as well as staff, faculty, post-docs, parents, alumnus/a, parents, and our New Haven neighbors.
Our church life is centered around Sunday worship in Yale's historic Battell Chapel, which features beautiful music, thoughtful preaching, and the prayer of a diverse, faithful community. Outside of Sunday mornings, we have lots of fun together with retreats, study groups, meals, concerts, lectures and other events.
UCY is an open and affirming congregation; we welcome persons of any denominational background (or none), race, ethnicity, age, nationality, sexual orientation, gender identity/expression, or physical or mental ability. Whether you are a life-long Christian, a questioning Christian, or new to Christianity, we hope that you feel at home with us.
goals: God calls us together to be an ecumenical Christian community in the midst of Yale University, extending an authentic and inclusive welcome to all Yale students, faculty, staff, and alumni, and all of the New Haven community.   We are called to worship the Triune God with joy and in beauty, to bring together lived faith, moral perspective and critical thought, and to serve our neighbors in the New Haven area and around the world.   As we remind ourselves each week, we are being formed by the Gospel of Jesus Christ into leaders and disciples who will do justice, love kindness, and walk humbly with God.

name: Visual Law Project
mission:
The Visual Law Project (VLP) curates workshops, lecture series, and visual media that foreground the increasingly important intersections between visual content and the law. We develop visual literacy within the YLS community and train law students to deploy visual content as a tool for advocacy.
Visual and digital technologies have transformed the practice of law.  Lawyers are using videos to present evidence, closing arguments, and victim-impact statements; advocates are making viral videos to advance public education campaigns; and scholars are debating ideas in a multimedia blogosphere.  Everyone's doing it.  But no one is really teaching it  or reflecting upon it.  We see training in visual advocacy  effectively evaluating and making arguments through videos and images  as a vital part of our legal education.
The Visual Law Project fosters a community of students invested in visual advocacy. We enable students to produce intellectually stimulating documentary films on legal issues to advance public debate. We organize an annual reading group centered on visual jurisprudence. We connect YLS students with innovative practitioners and thinkers through our speaker series. VLP operates both within and beyond the law school, and seeks to collaborate on interdisciplinary projects with graduate students in other programs.

name: Whim 'n Rhythm
mission:
As of 1981, Yale's vibrant a cappella scene featured a dozen underclassman groups of every variety. However, seven senior women felt that a key part of their musical experience was missing  a senior group. These seven seniors founded Whim n' Rhythm as an answer to the decades-old tradition of The Whiffenpoofs. Thirty-six years later, the 13 singers of Whim n' Rhythm represent the best and most experienced female musicians of the senior class.
Each year, Whim has continued to grow into a full-force presence on Yale's campus and on both the national and international stages. The group tours domestically and in the greater New England area yearly, visiting locations from New York and Los Angeles to Hong Kong and Cairo, and recently founded a full-fledged Alumnae Board to help build the group's legacy from beyond Yale's campus. Post-commencement, the group traditionally takes a five-to-seven week World Tour, hitting nearly every continent.
Prospective singers audition in the spring of their junior year to be tapped into Whim for their senior year the following fall. Whim represents nearly every underclassman singing group, a variety of residential colleges and academic majors, and hometowns ranging from coast to coast.

name: William F. Buckley, Jr. Program
mission: The mission of the William F. Buckley, Jr. Program is to promote intellectual diversity at Yale University. We aim to expand political discourse on campus and to expose students to often-unvoiced views. We believe that ideas have consequences and that genuine intellectual diversity is essential for advancing critical inquiry and avoiding ideological complacency. Our hope is that by providing a home for a diverse collection of serious conservative thought we can provide a forum for Yale students to consider and examine a range of political philosophies to which they are rarely exposed. As such, the purpose of this program is to foster open political discussion and intellectual engagement on campus.

name: WISAYale - a Student and Postdoc Organization
mission: As WISAY (Women and Gender Minorities in Science at Yale), we are dedicated to promoting the interests of female, transgender, and non-binary scientists and advocating for gender equality in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). Historically, only a small fraction of science degrees were awarded to women, but in recent decades, women's overall participation STEM fields has steadily increased. Today, women earn half of all bachelor's degrees in science. The involvement of women and gender minorities in advanced study and careers in STEM fields continues to grow. However, women are still underrepresented in many STEM fields and face significant challenges at the highest levels of these professions. WISAY seeks to help overcome these disparities by supporting women and gender minorities at all career levels through mentoring, networking, career development, and community building.

name: Yale Alternative Investments - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: YAI focuses on providing members experience in alternative investing: private equity, venture capital, real estate, and hedge funds. Through working on projects with established funds, members are given student internships, acquiring valuable hands-on financial experience while gaining insight into the mechanics of alternative investing.  Beyond project-based learning, YAI seeks to pursue deeper into the alternative investment space by inviting guest speakers and providing exclusive opportunities to network with industry professionals.  As Yale's first and only finance organization centered solely on alternative investing, YAI offers an unparalleled experience to contribute to multi-million and billion dollar investments as an undergraduate.
goals:
- Complete projects for industry leading firms across alternative investment types, including Private Equity, Venture Capital, and Real Estate.  In addition to working with the same hedge fund as last year, we will be expanding project offerings among other firms.
- Host guest speaker events on alternative investment for the larger Yale community.  Building upon last year's activity, we will continue to invite some of the most accomplished industry experts.
- Invite top PE and hedge funds to engage with club members for informational and recruitment purposes.  These opportunities currently do not exist at Yale.
- Organize team bonding and social events in as great a capacity as possible.  We believe that pre-professional clubs should actually exist as communities - it makes working together easier and more fun.  Becoming actual friends with each other is an important focus of the club.

name: Yale Biology and Biomedical Sciences Diversity and Inclusion Collective (YBDIC) - a Graduate Student Organization
mission: The Yale BBS Diversity and Inclusion Collective (YBDIC) is committed to fostering the intellectual and personal growth of underrepresented backgrounds in the BBS. Our central mission focuses on a four-pronged approach: engagement, empowerment, outreach, and advancement.
benefits:
The student engagement division aims to increase the representation of underrepresented scholars in BBS by advancing progressive recruitment initiatives coupled with student outreach to engage the next generation of scientists.
The student empowerment division tackles the historical legacy of patterns and practices that have led to the exclusion of underrepresented students in STEM. Through this division, we aim to both empower underrepresented students and address and alleviate historical and psychological burden that comes with being underrepresented in STEM. Through the appointment of dedicated YBDIC fellows for each track in BBS, we aim to create more inclusive training environments throughout the BBS program  and we believe this will culminate into institutional change.
The student outreach division focuses on providing access to science education and science communication opportunities and resources, available at Yale and within Yale's networks, to engage, empower, and advance underrepresented, disadvantaged, and marginalized individuals in the biological and biomedical sciences to increase career readiness.
The student advancement division is committed to preparing underrepresented students in BBS to successfully navigate the next stage of their academic career and transition into non-academic or academic sectors. By creating a dedicated faculty mentoring network and leveraging our alumni relationships, we will be able to provide underrepresented students with models and mentors as they traverse the next stage of their academic career. Collectively, through the concerted efforts of each branch we aim to foster individual empowerment and lasting institutional change.

name: Yale Biomedical Engineering Student Society
mission: The Yale Biomedical Engineering Society aims to increase awareness of the possibilities available through biomedical engineering, an interdisciplinary field in which the principles of basic science and engineering are applied to medicine. We hope to provide students at Yale with access to applied biomedical engineering in both academia and industry. We serve as a support network and forum for all biomedical engineering students to ask for advice or express their concerns in hopes of creating a strong, integrated major.
goals: The goals of the Yale Chapter of the Biomedical Engineering Society for 2020-2021 focus on increasing connections among BME students as well as providing resources to build their skill sets to launch them towards their dream internships at Yale and careers beyond Yale. Yale BMEs will host weekly webinars and tutorials that engage students in practicing engineering and design as well as recruit industry and research professionals to give talks about their careers and the possibilities that a BME degree allows for. Additionally, Yale BMES plans to host virtual designathons and hackathons to challenge teams of students to think outside the box and apply the knowledge they have gained from courses, life, and the society's webinars. This will be a year of growth and connections for BME students at Yale.

name: Yale Club Running Team
mission:
Yale Club Running welcomes all undergraduates (and graduate students) to run with us as a group. We offer multiple pace groups every day, and are far more focused on running together than running "fast." We do not hold try-outs, we do conduct organized -- and completely optional, occasionally overnight -- trips to cross country meets in the fall and track and marathon events in the spring. Track and other running workouts are held twice a week, but like all YCR events, workouts are totally optional. Alternate runs will always be available on workout days.
We're a friendly group, with a wide array of Yale experiences and backgrounds.
Join us to see Yale and New Haven in a new way!
goals:
- To run as a group
- To train for races (2020 fall races canceled) and a marathon in the spring
- To explore New Haven in all directions from Yale
- To have fun!

name: Yale Club Swim Team
mission:
Yale Club Swimming is a team of students from all corners of
campus life, with any range of experience, who come together due
to their love of swimming and the close-knit, family environment
that they find.
goals:
This year our organization hopes to offer a place of support and
community for members of the Yale Undergraduate class who
share a love of swimming. We are planning a multitude of socially
distanced team bonding events to keep the bonds within our swim
community strong, and forge new ones with the incoming class of
2024!

name: Yale Club Tae Kwon Do Team
category: Cultural, Health/Wellness, Performance: Other, Service/Volunteering, Sports/Outdoors
mission: Club Taekwondo at Yale is a co-ed sports club that offers a dynamic Korean martial arts experience for undergraduate students, graduate students, and Yale faculty. Club TKD has operated for almost 40 years at Yale and provides a welcoming community and training environment where students can learn, grow, and compete at various levels of competition. Through rigorous training, members develop physical fitness, self-defense skills, and mental discipline. The club emphasizes technique, sparring, and forms to enhance students' overall athleticism and confidence.
benefits: Get a great workout while learning self defense techniques and spending time with an amazing group of students from every major, background, and skill level possible!
goals: Develop physical fitness, self-defense skills, mental discipline, and a friendly community.

name: Yale Club Triathlon Team
mission: We are an all-inclusive group of undergraduate and graduate students who enjoy the sport of triathlon. We strive to create an environment where athletes of all skill levels can receive professional coaching and training in the sport they love. We also work hard to make an otherwise very expensive and elite sport affordable and accessible to students. Join us for fun swim/bike/run practices - no previous experience needed!
benefits: Access to practices in the pool and spin room, guidance from a professional triathlon coach, race opportunities, insider knowledge on local running/cycling/open water swim routes.
goals: Our goal as the Yale Club Triathlon Team is to train together in a fun and inclusive environment. We hold around six optional practices each week and compete in both sprint and Olympic distance triathlons as well as other races.

name: Yale Club Women's Rugby Team
mission: We are the Yale Women's Rugby Football Club! We come from all walks of life, and all joined rugby with varying experience (majority had never played) but eager to meet new people, and learn a new sport with fitness-minded people. We like to say that we are the fittest team on campus :)
benefits: We are a club sport, but get a lot of perks too. We have two amazing coaches, Craig Wilson and Alycia Washington that have exponential amount of experience. We get to workout in the weight room, and also get some cool gear.

name: Yale Journal on Regulation
mission: The Yale Journal on Regulation (JREG) is a biannual student-edited law review covering regulatory, administrative, corporate law topics. It is the top-ranked journal in the fields of corporate, administrative, bankruptcy, and commercial law in the United States.

name: Yale Club Wushu and Chinese Kung-fu Team
category: Cultural, Performance: Other, AACC Affiliate Org
mission:
The Yale Wushu team seeks to better its members in practice; by gaining focus and self-control
through intense training. Members hope to achieve self-mastery that will translate into respect
and compassion for others both inside and outside of the training hall.
Yale Wushu also seeks to better its community. The Yale Wushu team has been blessed by
many opportunities to spread the message of peace and nonviolence that lies at the center of
the word "wushu." Our classmates at Yale will go on to be leaders in their respective fields; it is
our hope that during our time here we succeed in spreading this message of peace to them. We
are also trying to spread this message to the city of New Haven.

name: Yale College Anime Society
mission: The purpose of the Yale College Anime Society is to allow people to appreciate East Asian culture--especially Japanese culture--through the lens of media and entertainment. We hope to give people the opportunity to explore genres and mediums they may have never explored. We primarily hope to do this through exposure to, discussion of, and analysis of Japanese Animation and Comics (i.e. "anime" and "manga"), Japanese music, and Japanese culture in general but will also look at manhwas, webtoons, light novels, and a variety of other mediums and genres . Through this, we aim to broaden the overall appeal and awareness of Eastern Asian media and entertainment, such as anime and manga, and increase the presence of this unique art form in the mainstream consciousness.
goals: We hope to give people the opportunity to explore genres and mediums they may not have previously experienced through exposure to and discussion/analysis of Japanese Animation and Comics (i.e. "anime" and "manga"), Japanese music, and Japanese culture in general. Occasionally we will also discuss manhwas, webtoons, light novels, and a variety of other mediums and genres. Through this, we aim to broaden the overall appeal and awareness of Eastern Asian media and entertainment, such as anime and manga, and increase the presence of this unique art form in the mainstream consciousness.

name: Yale College Council
mission: The purpose of YCC shall be to pursue the improvement of the Yale undergraduate experience by lending a voice to student concerns and opinions, shaping University policy, protecting student rights and freedoms, promoting and financing undergraduate organizations, fostering school unity and pride, and serving as a forum for the discussion and advancement of student ideas. We shall serve as the primary liaison between the undergraduate student body and the administration, graduate schools, faculty, staff, alumni, and persons or groups outside of the University. Any issue affecting the quality of undergraduate life or education falls within the jurisdiction of YCC.
goals:
1) Advocate for policy change within the college 2) Organize and sponsor student events & 3) Provide grassroots student services.
By way of these actions, we lend a voice to student concerns and opinions; protect student rights and freedoms; foster school unity and pride; and serve as a forum for the discussion and advancement of student ideas.

goals: Yale EMS will provide service in areas determined by its Executive Director and Medical Director for their designees, in consultation with Yale EMS. Areas of service may include but are not limited to: standby emergency medical service at athletic gatherings, campus-wide events (e.g. YHack, the YSO Halloween Show, Commencement, etc.), YEMS-sponsored EMT classes, and CPR/AED/First Aid classes.

name: Yale Environmental Law Association (YELA)
mission: The Yale Environmental Law Association (YELA) provides a home for students interested in environmental law and concerned about the climate crisis. YELA draws attention to all aspects of environmental law, environmental justice, and related fields through YLS community events, speakers and reading groups, and opportunities to connect and collaborate with other campus groups. YELA also serves as a hub for climate and environmental activism at YLS and beyond. YELA places special emphasis on the interdisciplinary, multifaceted character of environmental law and its relevance to a wide range of legal and policy issues.

name: Yale European Graduate Student Society
mission: We bring together European students and European culture enthusiasts at the graduate and professional level at Yale for the purpose of fostering friendships, networking, and discussion. This group serves both as an informal and formal way to network, meet speakers, and have conversations about topics related to Europe.

name: Yale Existential Threats Initiative - A Student Organization
mission: The Yale Existential Threats Initiative - A Student Organization (YETI) is a student organization that aims to motivate and prepare students to pursue careers and projects reducing existential risks.

name: Yale Federalist Society
mission: The Federalist Society is founded on three core principles: We believe that the state exists to preserve freedom. We believe that the separation of governmental powers is central to our Constitution. And we believe that it is emphatically the province and duty of the judiciary to say what the law is, not what it should be.

name: Yale Food Law Society
mission: The Yale Food Law Society (FoodSoc) is a nonpartisan community that promotes the study of and engagement with food and agriculture law and policy. FoodSoc advocates an approach that is economically, environmentally, and socially sustainable.

name: Yale Foreign Policy Initiative - An Undergraduate Organization
category: Academic, Advocacy/Policy, International Affairs, Leadership, Political, Pre-Professional, Professional, Publication, Science/Technology, International
address: New Haven, Conn 06520 United States
mission: The Yale Foreign Policy Initiative (YFPI) is a student-run organization dedicated to the creation of comprehensive and research-backed solutions to tackle the world's leading foreign affairs issues. Partnering with think tanks, government agencies, and the Jackson School in pursuit of policy research, YFPI seeks to prepare generations of Yale undergraduates for careers in foreign service and international relations.

name: Yale Forest Forum
address:
360 Prospect Street
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: The Yale Forest Forum offers weekly lunch talks during the academic year, providing opportunities to hear from leaders in forest management, conservation, or policy in an informal setting. The YFF speaker series is the longest continuously-running speaker series at the Yale School of the Environment. Speakers come from a wide range of organizations and perspectives, including government, NGOs and businesses, working at scales from local to international.

mission: The Yale Graduate Muslim Students Association provides those who are affiliated with the University in a post-undergraduate capacity a space to interact and socialize with other Muslim-identifying people on campus. The Yale Graduate Muslim Students Association is committed to fostering a sense of community across the University's many graduate and professional schools.

name: Yale Graduate Rugby Football Club
mission: This club has active Men's and Women's teams and provides the opportunity to break out of the bubble of your graduate program and make friends from all the other graduate schools, as well as meeting graduate students from around the world on the teams we play against, all while competing in one of the world's greatest sports - rugby. Each year, YGRFC participates in some of the greatest Rugby Tournaments across the country, including Hogfest at Wharton in the fall, as well as the MBA Rugby World Cup in New York in the spring.

name: Yale Graduate Society of Women Engineers
mission: The Graduate Society of Women Engineers (gradSWE) is a forum to connect grad students interested in the inclusion of women in engineering within the broader engineering community. Through our activities, we seek to provide both personal and professional development, in order to support female engineering students on the path to an advanced degree and in their careers after graduating.

name: Yale Graduate Student Christian Fellowship
mission:
We are a community of Christians who encourage one another in developing our gifts, education and passions to glorify God in our current scholarship and future professions. We seek to engage other graduate students and the broader Yale and New Haven communities with Christ's message of God's love that renews and redeems the world.
As an affiliated chapter of the Graduate and Faculty Ministry (GFM) of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, we also embrace their mission statement, which is:  The mission of GFM is to encourage and equip graduate students and faculty to follow Christ as they seek to be a redeeming influence among the people, ideas, and structures of the university and professions.
We invite you to join our e-mail list to stay informed about our activities: http://mailman.yale.edu/mailman/listinfo/ygcf

name: Yale Graduate Student Consulting Club
mission: Our mission at the YGCC is to provide a platform for Yale graduate students to learn about and prepare for productive careers in management consulting by transforming Yale into a prime recruiting ground for top firms.

name: Yale GSAS Student Blockchain and Cryptocurrency Club
mission: Build a Decentralized, Cohesive & Supportive Ecosystem for every Yalie who has passion in Blockchain and Cryptocurrency
goals:
Yale GSAS Student Blockchain and Cryptocurrency Club is a non-profit student-run club and devoted to support local community to thrive in blockchain and cryptocurrency. The goals are but not limited to:
1. We aim to educate graduate students and greater community on the technology, application, investment strategy and market of blockchain and cryptocurrency by inviting  speakers from academy and industry .
2. We aim to to provide a platform for cross-campus interdisciplinary collaborations and tech innovations in the fields of blockchain and cryptocurrency via seminars and workshops.
3. We aim to provide group members with professional networks, career opportunities and exclusive internship through the connections with our off-campus collaborators and Yale alumni.
4. We aim to organize standing study groups and social events to boost learning efficiency and group cohesion.

name: Yale Immigrant Justice Project
address: New Haven, Conn
mission: The Yale Immigrant Justice Project (IJP) organizes law students in support of immigrant communities in the Greater New Haven area and around the country. Law students engage in projects involving direct legal services, assisting with strategic litigation, and drafting appeals of immigration decisions. As they stand, immigration policies exist to disorient and dehumanize those who wish to make their home in the U.S. We envision a different future in which no one has to live in fear because of their documentation status. We hope to use the skills, privileges, and opportunities our law degrees give us to work towards making that a reality.

name: Yale Journal of Law and Feminism
mission: The Yale Journal of Law and Feminism is committed to publishing scholarship on gender, sexuality, and the law, especially insofar as the law structures, affects, or ignores the experiences of women and other marginalized peoples. We encourage the submission of articles, essays, and reviews concerning these intersections of law and feminism. As we promote feminist principles to our readers, we also practice those principles ourselves. All members contribute to our Journal's management, making major decisions through modified consensus.

name: Yale Jewish Law Students' Association
mission: The Yale Jewish Law Students Association (JLSA) is an affinity group that organizes and hosts academic, cultural, religious, and social events including Shabbat and holiday meals, faculty dinners, and lectures.

name: Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine
mission: The Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine (YJBM) is a graduate and medical student-run, peer-reviewed, open-access journal dedicated to the publication of original research articles, scientific reviews, articles on medical history, personal perspectives on medicine, policy analyses, case reports, and symposia related to biomedical matters. YJBM is published quarterly and aims to publish articles of interest to both physicians and scientists. YJBM is and has been an internationally distributed journal with a long history of landmark articles. Our contributors feature a notable list of philosophers, statesmen, scientists, and physicians, including Ernst Cassirer, Harvey Cushing, Rene Dubos, Edward Kennedy, Donald Seldin, and Jack Strominger. Our Editorial Board consists of students and faculty members from Yale School of Medicine and Yale University Graduate School of Arts & Sciences. All manuscripts submitted to YJBM are first evaluated on the basis of scientific quality, originality, appropriateness, contribution to the field, and style. Suitable manuscripts are then subject to rigorous, fair, and rapid peer review.

YJIA seeks to embody the values and vision of the Jackson School for Global Affairs with which it is affiliated, chiefly by presenting arguments that address the real world and policy implications of the issues it covers.
YJIA was established in 2004 by graduate students at Yale University's MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies. Since 2011, YJIA has been proudly associated with Yale's Jackson School of Global Affairs.

name: Yale Pizza Society
mission:
The Yale Pizza Society (YPS) seeks to explore the history and tradition of pizza within the Yale and New Haven communities. Students in the organization will have a space to share their love of pizza through discussions, presentations, articles, and field trips. Above all, the Yale Pizza Society strives to create a greater sense of appreciation for the one-of-a-kind pizza culture that exists in New Haven.
The Yale Pizza Society will host weekly/biweekly meetings to explore the New Haven pizza scene. These meetings can take the form of a presentation on the history of pizza in New Haven, a discussion on what makes a good pizza, a guest speaker with an expertise on New Haven Pizza, or a trip to a pizza restaurant in New Haven. The possibilities are endless as long as the meetings are centered around pizza. The Yale Pizza Society will maintain a presence online through various social media channels and a dedicated website. On these platforms, photos, reviews, infographics, interviews, and videos, all revolving around pizza, will be shared. The culminating project for the Yale Pizza Society will be a ranked list of the top pizza restaurants in New Haven, as determined by the members of the Yale Pizza Society. This ranking will be published once per academic year with the winning restaurant awarded a Yale Pizza Society plaque.

name: Yale Precision Marching Band
mission:
The Yale Bands is a thriving cultural community. Its members are given opportunities to prepare and perform great music; learn about the arts and their place in society and international cultures; and develop skills to become leaders. Through a robust series of musical activities, many Bands members work with and become serious performers, conductors, composers, arrangers, writers, archivists, historians, photographers, producers, choreographers, media producers, critics, and teachers. Band members develop and master these skills through service to the University, performing and producing commencement music, benefit concerts, university ceremonies, theater shows, international tours, reading sessions for classes, and special events.
The YPMB is one of twelve scatter-style marching bands in the country. What does this mean? Most marching bands spend their time on field spelling their name in script or making a swirly line formation while playing the complete works of Andrew Lloyd Webber. We perform halftime shows composed of comedy segments, during which we spell witty things on the field and play really cool rock music. Between formations we run around wildly (hence the clever name "scatter band"). For example: in the past we've done a sketch about the rise and fall of Saddam Hussein as a Yale professor, accompanied to "It's Gonna Be Me" and "Live and Let Die," one in which we played the "Godfather" theme and dug up Jimmy Hoffa on the 30-yard-line (this was during our trip to Giants Stadium) and the unforgettable George W. Bush sketch, which involved a line of white-shirted bandies and the playing of Eric Clapton's "Cocaine." We are also a pep band. During the winter we support Yale's hockey and basketball teams every weekend. This time of year often leads to playoff travel; we've been to Lake Placid, Ann Arbor, MI, MADISON SQUARE GARDEN, and more. We are a mobile attack unit. If there's anywhere on the Yale campus (or, really, the East Coast - we're flexible) that needs some relief from pretension, we'll be there to provide.
We could go on for pages trying to tell you what we are. You'd be best off to show up and find out, really. You won't be disappointed.
For more, visit us here: https://bands.yalecollege.yale.edu/bands/yale-precision-marching-band/frequently-asked-questions

name: Yale Students Against Wrongful Convictions
mission:
Mission Yale Students Against Wrongful Convictions ("YSAWC")
aims to help remedy, prevent, and increase public awareness of
convictions that violate the precept of proof beyond a reasonable
doubt, fair trial rights, or the other procedural rights of criminal
defendants. In addition to the significant harm to the individuals
directly affected by these convictions, these miscarriages of justice
fundamentally undermine the legitimacy of and public faith in the
criminal justice system. Our mission is threefold: First, we will
provide legal assistance in the fight against real cases of wrongful
convictions; Second, we will educate students on the common and
systemic causes of wrongful convictions and the difficulties in
challenging them; Third, through confronting wrongful convictions,
we hope to encourage students to think critically about how the
criminal justice system creates unjust obstacles for all defendants
regardless of whether they are "guilty" and disproportionately
harms the poor, people of color, and other disadvantaged groups.

name: Yale Students for RCV
mission: Yale Students for Ranked Choice Voting is a nonpartisan organization dedicated to promoting awareness of ranked choice voting (RCV) in the Yale community and beyond. In doing so, we seek to rally support for this reform, which will reduce the temperature of our bitter political climate and make elections more truly democratic and representative of the diversity of identities and ideas of the population as a whole.

name: Yale Supreme Court Society
mission: As individuals from all political perspectives come together, our mission is to foster an intellectual and dynamic space to seriously and respectfully discuss and debate legal and constitutional issues. We strive for philosophical consistency in navigating the intersection of government and morality. The foundational basis for our discussions will be provided by previous and ongoing Supreme Court cases.

name: Yale Undergraduate Student Dairy Association

name: Yale Swing, Blues, and Fusion
category: Arts: Other, Arts: Visual Arts, Cultural, Health/Wellness, Performance: Dance, Performance: Other, Social, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission:
Yale Swing, Blues, and Fusion is the non-competitive swing and blues dancing community on campus and in the New Haven area. We provide a space for people to get together and dance in a fun, informal setting.
COMMUNITY
Yale Swing, Blues, & Fusion is an intentional dance community. We intend to be a friendly, welcoming, including, and safe space. By entering our community, we ask that you help us uphold those values.
INCLUSIVITY
We strive to give a good time to everyone coming to our community. To help us do that, we ask everyone to dance, regardless of their gender, age, race, religion, sexual orientation or experience! It's more fun when everybody's dancing! We also like to talk to people in a friendly way! Treat people as your fellow human beings!
CONSENT
Both on the dance floor and outside of it, we make sure to ask someone's consent before we do anything. We ask people to dance verbally, and if they want to lead or follow, or if they may dance your preferred role.
If anyone makes someone else uncomfortable, they will be held accountable for doing so. Accidents happen, but it doesn't mean someone doesn't have to apologize!
If anyone is uncomfortable during a dance, we encourage them to ask for more space, a lighter touch, or anything they need. If they don't feel safe, they can walk away from the dance. Please let an organizer know if they're feeling discomfort!
It's perfectly fine to turn down a dance. Be gracious and move on!
COLLABORATIVE WORK
We hope that everyone who finds these values awesome will share them! If anyone sees behavior that seems to not be respecting those values, we can encourage them to either address it with that person or with an organizer.
Our community is run by members of GSAS and the community and is completely based on volunteering work.

name: Yale Undergraduate Law Journal
mission: The Yale Undergraduate Law Journal is a student-written and student-run journal of legal scholarship. As the only pre-law publication on campus, the YULJ aims to reach a wide interdisciplinary audience by allowing its writers to explore the various aspects of law which they may find interesting or relevant in our time. The journal has three branches: a Law Journal, which is a semi-annual publication featuring long-form papers, published in print and digital forms; a Blog, which is a digital platform that frequently publishes shorter-form articles on pressing legal issues; and a Podcast, which is an audio platform where legal scholars can regularly be hosted and where we can cover law-related news, domestically and internationally.

name: Yale University Chaplain's Office
mission: This is a word that we in the Yale University Chaplain's Office use and enthusiastically commit to putting into practice often.  The very foundation of the work that we do at Yale is about creating an environment that feels welcoming to all people.  Whether you are part of a particular religious/spiritual community or not, we welcome you!  This website is designed to give you a deeper sense of the kind of work that we do at Yale as well as to promote religious literacy for the greater purpose of fostering understanding and appreciation of global religious and spiritual traditions.  Whether you are visiting this site to find out more about how to connect with a particular individual, group or space, to learn about our events and programs or just to explore in general, we hope that you find what you need and that you even discover something new along the way that feeds your soul.  We hope that you visit this site or our office often.  You are always welcome!

name: Yale Venture Club for Students and Scholars
mission:
1.	Yale Venture Club is an independent, non-political, and non-profit organization dedicated to promoting social and intellectual networking for all students within the Yale community, particularly for graduate students interested in equity investment and entrepreneurship.
2.	Unite entrepreneurs, industry experts, VC/PE investors, and all others with a genuine interest in the venture field among the Yale community.
3.	Establish a strong and long-lasting connection among all club members (including but not limited to current students and alumni across all Yale schools).
4.	Aim to connect investors and startups resources within and beyond the Yale community to help further the growth of venture capital talents and startup founders, thus further enhancing the influence among different communities beyond the Yale campus.

name: Yale Vermilion Theater for Students and Scholars
category: Cultural, Performance: Theater, AACC Affiliate Org
mission: We are inspired to perform plays with bilingual (Mandarin and English) versions, so as to facilitate cultural conversations and build a bridge between the theater work based in these two language mediums. We also see great value in forming such a cultural club in light of the spike in anti-AAPI sentiments since the start of the pandemic. We are naming the club "Vermilion Theater" as the vermilion bird (a phoenix-like being) is a symbol of tenacity and resilience in Chinese mythology. As we learn about the possibility of safely returning to theater in a world forever changed by COVID, we hope that our organization will bring long-isolated people together, share a sense of normalcy and build a much needed community.

name: YSPH Climate Change and Health Concentration
type: Yale School of Public Health Departments and Programs
mission:
Climate change represents the greatest public health challenge of the 21st century, and has profound implications for human health, today and in the future. To this end, the Yale Center on Climate Change and Health (CCCH) utilizes research, education, public health practice, and service to help achieve a world with a stable and safe climate; one in which the public's health and diverse ecosystems can thrive.
The YSPH Concentration in Climate Change and Health will work to address the severe shortage of public health professionals with the educational background needed to address climate change as a public health issue.
The study of climate change and health is multi-disciplinary and should interest students from all YSPH departments. Climate change is an environmental exposure (Dept. of Environmental Health Sciences) that can affect both infectious (Dept. of Epidemiology of Microbial Diseases) and chronic (Dept. of Chronic Disease Epidemiology) diseases. Research about the relationship between climate change and health can involve sophisticated modeling (Dept. of Biostatistics and others). Behavioral change, mental health, and social justice are major concerns (Dept. of Social and Behavioral Sciences). Finally, health management expertise is needed to develop mitigation and adaptation strategies, and climate change involves thorny policy issues (Dept. of Health Policy and Management).

name: YSPH Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Belonging
address: New Haven, CT  United States
mission: Across the YSPH community, the dean, faculty, staff and the alumni have adopted mentorship, recruitment, retention and professional development practices to help meet our goal of having an outstanding and diverse School of Public Healtha place that better reflects the local, national and international communities we study. The Diversity Ambassadors at YSPH exist to serve as advocates for students and liaisons between the student affinity groups and the larger Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Belonging Committee (DEIB).

name: YSPH Global Health Concentration
mission:
The Yale School of Public Health is a leader in Yale University's commitment to improve health across the globe through research, education and community engagement. The School uses science to foster health, promote innovation, train leaders and make a difference in the world. Faculty research spans a variety of fields including chronic and infectious diseases, implementation science, environmental health, behavioral determinants of health, and policy and administration.
The Global Health Concentration builds on all these experiences and emphasizes an integrative problemsolving approach to global health issues and to diseases and conditions that afflict developing and developed countries.
Students who complete this concentration will be well prepared for positions in a variety of organizationspublic and private, national, bilateral and multilateraldedicated to global health challenges.
